topic_metadata.title: How do I create an inline heading without first-line-indent?

posts.name: Constantin Gahr
posts.cooked:
I want to create an inline heading, similar to the \paragraph*{} command in latex.

The proposed solution I found here

#show heading.where(level: 4): it => block(strong(it.body) + [ ])

works somewhat well. However, I use

#set par(first-line-indent: 1.8em)

to indent the first line of a paragraph. Using the above solution, the inline heading is also indented, which I do not want. Instead, I want by formatting to be this:

INLINE HEADING some text  for this a heading. And
some more text.

   A new paragraph under this heading. Observe that it 
is indented, in contrast the the heading!

How do I do this?
posts.raw:
I want to create an inline heading, similar to the `\paragraph*{}` command in latex.

The proposed solution I found [here](https://forum.typst.app/t/inline-heading-does-not-work-with-additional-linebreak/1067)
```typ
#show heading.where(level: 4): it => block(strong(it.body) + [ ])
```
works somewhat well. However, I use 
```typ
#set par(first-line-indent: 1.8em)
```
to indent the first line of a paragraph. Using the above solution, the inline heading is also indented, which I do not want. Instead, I want by formatting to be this:
```txt
INLINE HEADING some text  for this a heading. And
some more text.

   A new paragraph under this heading. Observe that it 
is indented, in contrast the the heading!
```
How do I do this?

posts.cooked:
#show heading.where(level: 4): it => {
  h(-1.8em)
  box(strong(it.body))
}

posts.name: Constantin Gahr
posts.cooked:
I like it, thank you!

However, this can fail after a list or an equation:

This is a list:
- arst
- arst

==== This is indented beyond the boundary of the page

$
 1 = 0
$

==== This is also indented too much

How do I fix this?
posts.raw:
I like it, thank you!

However, this can fail after a list or an equation:
```typ
This is a list:
- arst
- arst

==== This is indented beyond the boundary of the page

$
 1 = 0
$

==== This is also indented too much
```
How do I fix this?

posts.cooked:
Unfortunately Typst’s paragraph handling isn’t very consistent so you can’t do this automatically. The easiest way I see would be to define a command that adds the appropriate spacing and call it before every incorrectly indented heading:

#let indent = h(1.8em)

This is a list:
- arst
- arst

#indent
==== This is indented correctly

$
 1 = 0
$

#indent
==== This is fixed as well

posts.cooked: I see, that’s a pity. Let’s hope I won’t regret writing my thesis with it. Thanks a lot!

posts.cooked:
Hi, I needed the same and used the following snippet. It worked perfectly for me, maybe it helps.

#show heading.where(level: 4): it => block(spacing: 0.65em) + box(strong(it.body) + [ ])
Result

posts.name: tpaelman
posts.cooked:
I adjusted the snippet from @flokl:

#show heading.where(level: 4): it => block(below: 0pt) + box(strong(it.body))
// Not exactly sure what the `+ [ ]` was doing there anyway...

Since blocks inherit spacing from paragraphs, you normally will get the same spacing as between paragraphs. The below: 0pt is needed to only use it from one side
(if not, you’ll see a large gap - try to use a plain block())
posts.raw:
I adjusted the snippet from @flokl:

```typst
#show heading.where(level: 4): it => block(below: 0pt) + box(strong(it.body))
// Not exactly sure what the `+ [ ]` was doing there anyway...
```
Since blocks inherit `spacing` from paragraphs, you normally will get the same spacing as between paragraphs. The `below: 0pt` is needed to only use it from one side
(if not, you'll see a large gap - try to use a plain `block()`)
